author: James Clear
summary: A practical guide to building better habits and breaking bad ones using small, consistent improvements.
keyTakeaways: Tiny changes compound into remarkable results.
Focus on systems, not goals.
Identity-based habits are the most powerful.
whoShouldRead: Anyone looking to improve daily productivity, consistency, or mindset.
myTakeaway: This book taught me that consistency matters more than intensity — it changed how I approach learning.

author: Cal Newport
summary: Explores the value of deep, focused work in a distracted digital age.
keyTakeaways: Deep work is like a superpower in the modern world.
Distraction destroys both focus and fulfillment.
Routines and rituals enable concentration.
whoShouldRead: Knowledge workers, students, and creators seeking to boost focus.
myTakeaway: Helped me design distraction-free work blocks — now my output is 3x higher.

author: Morgan Housel
summary: A book that explains how personal behavior and mindset shape our financial success more than knowledge.
keyTakeaways: Wealth is what you don’t see — savings, not spending.
Luck and risk play invisible roles in success.
Managing money is more about emotions than equations.
whoShouldRead: Anyone interested in financial literacy, mindset, or investing.
myTakeaway: Shifted my focus from income to freedom — financial peace matters more than status.

author: David Goggins
summary: A raw story of resilience, pain, and mental toughness from a Navy SEAL who redefined his limits.
keyTakeaways: You are capable of 40% more than you think.
Embrace suffering to build strength.
Discipline is stronger than motivation.
whoShouldRead: Anyone struggling with self-discipline, fitness, or mental strength.
myTakeaway: Every time I face self-doubt, I remember Goggins’ 'Callous the mind' mantra.

bookTitle: Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products
author: Nir Eyal
summary: A breakdown of how successful apps and products keep users coming back through behavioral design.
keyTakeaways: The Hook Model: Trigger → Action → Reward → Investment.
Products that help users achieve goals become habits.
Design ethically — avoid manipulation.
whoShouldRead: Product managers, UX designers, developers, or entrepreneurs.
myTakeaway: Changed how I view app design — user habits are built, not bought.

bookTitle: Sapiens: A Brief History of Humankind
author: Yuval Noah Harari
summary: A sweeping history of humanity that connects biology, anthropology and culture to explain how Homo sapiens came to dominate the planet.
keyTakeaways: Large-scale human cooperation is built on shared myths.
Agricultural revolution changed social structures more than diets.
Science and capitalism propelled rapid modern change.
whoShouldRead: Readers interested in history, culture, and big-picture thinking.
myTakeaway: Gave me a new lens to view societal change and modern institutions.

author: Eric Ries
summary: A methodology for building startups and new products with fast experimentation, validated learning and iterative design.
keyTakeaways: Build–Measure–Learn loop shortens product-market fit discovery.
Minimum Viable Product reduces wasteful development.
Pivot when data shows current strategy is not working.
myTakeaway: Started testing assumptions earlier in my projects and saved months of work.

author: Daniel Kahneman
summary: Explains two modes of thought — fast, intuitive thinking and slow, deliberative thinking — and how they shape judgment and decision-making.
keyTakeaways: System 1 (fast) and System 2 (slow) govern our thinking.
Cognitive biases systematically affect decisions.
Awareness of biases can improve choices but doesn’t remove them.
whoShouldRead: Anyone who wants to make better decisions or understand human bias.
myTakeaway: Now I pause before big decisions and check for bias.

author: Paulo Coelho
summary: A fable about following your personal legend, filled with simple but powerful life lessons.
keyTakeaways: Pursue your personal legend and learn from the journey.
The universe conspires to help you when you commit.
Meaning is found in listening to your heart and acting.
whoShouldRead: Readers who enjoy spiritual, philosophical fiction.
myTakeaway: Reminded me that small signs and persistence matter.

author: Tara Westover
summary: A memoir about a woman who grows up isolated and self-educated, ultimately escaping to gain a formal education.
keyTakeaways: Education expands the way you see the world.
Family ties can be both supporting and limiting.
Personal transformation is often a painful process.
whoShouldRead: Readers interested in resilience, family dynamics, and education.
myTakeaway: Powerful story about the cost and value of education.

author: Don Miguel Ruiz
summary: Four simple agreements to adopt for personal freedom and reduced suffering.
keyTakeaways: Be impeccable with your word.
Don't take things personally.
Don't make assumptions and always do your best.
myTakeaway: Simple rules that improved my daily interactions.

bookTitle: Grit: The Power of Passion and Perseverance
author: Angela Duckworth
summary: Examines how sustained passion and perseverance (grit) predict long-term success more than talent alone.
keyTakeaways: Effort counts twice toward achievement.
Grit combines passion and sustained practice.
Growth mindset complements grit-building.
whoShouldRead: Students, educators, and anyone building long-term skills.
myTakeaway: Shifted focus from talent to consistent effort.

author: Peter Thiel
summary: Insights on building companies that create new things rather than copying existing models.
keyTakeaways: Aim for monopoly by solving unique problems.
Progress comes from secrets and technology.
Think long-term and plan defensively.
myTakeaway: Encouraged more ambitious, original product thinking.

author: Chip Heath & Dan Heath
summary: Explains why some ideas survive and spread while others die, with practical techniques to make messages stick.
keyTakeaways: Use simplicity, unexpectedness and concreteness.
Emotion and stories help ideas spread.
Analogies and examples make concepts memorable.

bookTitle: Essentialism: The Disciplined Pursuit of Less
author: Greg McKeown
summary: A guide to focusing on the few vital things and eliminating the trivial many.
keyTakeaways: Clarity comes from subtraction, not addition.
Say no to protect time for what matters most.
Small trade-offs lead to better priorities.
whoShouldRead: Busy professionals and people wanting focus.
myTakeaway: Helped me create a clearer weekly priority list.
